table_items.text: Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:

data.text: Contents
Introduction

A Cannula is a flexible tube containing the stylet which may be inserted into a blood vessel (RCN 2016). Peripheral Cannulation provides access for the purpose of intravenous (IV) hydration, administration of medicines and blood products. Cannulas are usually inserted for short-term therapy as well for bolus injections or short infusions. Cannulation of the lower extremities (Foot) should not be routine (with the exemption of neonates and infants) unless in the case of an emergency (Infusion Nurses Society (INS), 2021).

Peripheral intravenous cannulation is a commonly performed procedure but has an associated risk of phlebitis and infiltration (Simin et al, 2018) as well as a risk of infection because of the potential for direct microbial entry to the bloodstream.

A Midline is a peripheral vascular access device: longer than a peripheral cannula but shorter than a PiCC. Typically, they are 8-25cms in length. They are sited into an upper arm vein but the tip remains in the peripheral circulation, below the level of the axillary line. They can remain insitu for up to 28 days of treatment as long as there are no complications (RCN, 2016)
As the line does not sit in a central vein it should be treated as a cannula. The position does not need to be verified by x-ray or ECG tip positioning device

Blood stream infections associated with insertion and maintenance of vascular access devices are among the most serious complications that can occur (Zhang et al, 2016), worsening the severity of a patient's underlying ill health, prolonging hospitalisation and increasing cost of care.

The micro-organisms that colonise catheter hubs and the skin adjacent to the insertion site are primarily the source of most catheter related bloodstream infections (CR-BSI) (Zhang et al, 2016). Coagulase negative Staphylococci, particularly Staphylococcus epidermis are the most frequently implicated micro- organisms associated with CR-BSI. Other micro-organisms commonly involved include Staphylococcus aureus, Candida species and enterococci.

CR-BSI are caused by cutaneous micro-organisms that contaminate the catheter during insertion or migrate along the catheter tract when in situ, or by micro- organisms from the hands of Health Care Workers (HCWs) that contaminate and colonise the catheter hub during manipulation (Zhang et al, 2016).

Prevention of infection is the responsibility of all Health Care Workers. Effective infection prevention must be embedded as everyday practice in health and social care practice to ensure the safety of everyone (Department of Health, 2015). The implications of not identifying and containing infection can be detrimental to the patient, which may lead them to seek financial compensation. In addition, there are the increased costs of treating infections with antibiotics and extended hospital stays. This policy sets out standards for peripheral cannulation and intravenous care of peripheral devises to facilitate this high-quality care and accountability.
The Trust must show that it has a robust insertion, management and removal protocol, which takes into account Evidence Based Practice in Infection Control

epic3 guidelines (Loveday et al, 2014). Audits will be undertaken, ensuring optimum practice to protect patients from subsequent complications as per National institute for Health and Social Care Excellence (NICE) (2014) Guidelines.
Safety devices should be used preferentially wherever they are suitable and available, to protect the practitioner.

Nurses should be familiar with this policy and the guideline within it when undertaking the cannulation procedure within Mid and South Essex (MSE) Trust Hospital and any national guidelines i.e.; NICE Guidelines/epic3, relating to the procedure. The individual nurse is accountable for maintaining their knowledge and skills (Nursing and Midwifery Council, 2018).
Scope

This is an advanced clinical skill which can only be performed by staff that have completed the Trust's formal training for cannulation and have been assessed as competent. The purpose of this document is to ensure all healthcare professionals responsible for undertaking cannulation insertion and/or caring for a peripherally inserted device; cannula or MIDline following insertion, within the Trust, are provided with a clearly defined process by which their competence can be assessed to ensure their practice is safe and effective.
This policy is designed to;
Ensure that all practitioners are competent to perform IV cannulation.
Ensure that practitioners perform IV cannulation safely and effectively.
To ensure that all practitioners continue to care for the IV cannula/MIDline once insitu and deliver intravenous (IV) medication to a Trust standard.
Definitions

table_items.text: a qualified and registered healthcare professional who has been trained and assessed as competent in intravenous procedures. This will include nurses, allied health professionals and medical personnel
The presence of gas in blood vessels, which can cause an interruption of normal blood flow
Aseptic non touch technique; a method of preventing contamination through the protection of key parts or sites that are sterile, or have been decontaminated.
An abnormal channel or passage between an artery and a vein.
Band 4 Associate Practitioners or Nursing Associates.
Other non-registered nursing staff in specialist areas, as

specifically identified by a Head of Nursing/Midwifery. Specialist areas are: A&E; The AMU's, X-ray department and the Haematology Day Unit. Student Nurses and Midwives (Currently under review) Competency assessments for this group will be undertaken by a Clinical Nurse Educator/ Practice education facilitator /Development Nurse Specialist/Education Lead Nurse or Band 6 Sister/Charge Nurse.

a circular sponge patch impregnated with Chlorhexidine placed at the insertion site surrounding the line, to provide an exclusion zone preventing the regrowth of microorganisms. This can absorb exudate and needs to be changed weekly, or earlier if full of fluid. This is only used with a MIDline
Draw up needle, large bore, safety device with 45° tip to reduce risk of coring. Suitable for reconstitution of medication from vials with an injectable top and drawing up from plastic ampoules

Draw up needle, large bore, safety device with 45° tip to reduce risk of coring, includes a filter to prevent aspiration of glass particles when using glass ampoules that are snapped open. NB not suitable for lipid solutions.
a standard hypodermic needle (non -safety). Alternative for use in preparing intravenous flushes / medications if a blunt fill / blunt fill filter needle is unavailable or unsuitable
is the term used for the procedure of inserting a peripheral cannula into a vein.
Central Intravenous Additives (service), aseptic unit in pharmacy
The accidental leakage of vesicant fluids into the tissues
The accidental leakage of non-vesicant fluids into the tissues
Sclerosis or hardening to the skin and tissue
A checklist to ensure compliance with insertion, maintenance and removal of an invasive device
An accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the interstitial tissues of the body, caused by the blockage of lymph vessels
Pertaining to or emanating from a microbe.

A Midline is a peripheral vascular access device; longer than a standard peripheral cannula they range between 8 cm and 20cm in length and have an extended dwell time of 2 – 6 weeks. They may be single or double lumen devices. This device is only inserted in Interventional radiology.
Learning conducted via electronic media, typically on the internet.
is a generic term which includes neonates
Inflammation of the inner lining of the vein
Visual Infusion Phlebitis score, (see appendix II) a method of assessing the cannula site
Mixing a powdered drug with a suitable diluent, to allow intravenous medicines administration.
A subcutaneous stabilisation device, can only be sited at the time of line insertion and is retained for the duration of the placement. This is only used with a MIDline
Micro-organisms which reside on the skin surface; usually non- pathogenic and offer protective role

An adhesive external fixation device on the patient's skin, the device clips into it, holding it in place. Requires changing when loose or soiled This is primarily used with a MIDline, but can be used with a peripheral cannula too.
Is the part of the cardiovascular system which carries oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body and returns deoxygenated blood back to the heart.
Venous inflammation which can lead to venous thrombosis and could then cause vessel occlusion.
Refers to Mid and South Essex National Health Service Trust
An observation tool used for monitoring the cannula site
A caustic medication that causes tissue to possibly blister and cause necrosis if extravasation occurs.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Infection Prevention and Control Committee: to ensure infection prevention and control policy is upheld.
Practice Education Committee: to ensure policy regarding education for cannulation for all staff and Student Nurses and Midwives is upheld in align with the Nursing and midwifery Council proficiency.
Medication Assurance Group: to ensure the procedures used for cannulation flushing is within MSE Trust agreed standards.
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation  of  this  document  is  available.  He/she  will  delegate  the  full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Directors:

The  Medical  Director  is  responsible  for  ensuring  that  the  necessary  systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Directors of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Directors of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial  action  implemented  as  appropriate.  In  addition,  the  Divisional  Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers:

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Associate Director of Nursing/Midwifery:

The ADoN/M of each directorate is responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers:

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Head of Therapies:

The Head of Therapies (HoT) is responsible for ensuring that this document is fully implemented at department level. This will include making sure all relevant and necessary training is given and received, that the introduction of the document is monitored and therefore assessing the impact this is having on service delivery. In addition, the HoT is responsible for ensuring that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken within the Therapy CSU and reported through the relevant governance system.
Supervisors of Midwives:

The SoM is statutorily responsible for document development, implementation and compliance monitoring across the midwifery spectrum. They are accountable to the LSMO for all elements of midwifery professional performance.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document.
PiCC Team
Provide pre-assessment, insertion and post-insertion follow-up on all patients with MIDlines/PiCC's.

Ensure relevant education and information is provided to patients, colleagues and other relevant health care professionals with regard to the care of MIDline and will ensure an appropriate care plan is in place for all patients following MIDline/PiCC insertion.
Participate with colleagues in audit, review and evaluation of the service and in research and trials related to vascular access devices
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Clinical Nurse Educator (CNE)/ Practice Education Facilitators (PEF)/ Practice Development Team
CNS's/PEF's are involved in the development of clinical competencies.

They facilitate the learning of practical skills within the clinical environment, once theoretical learning has taken place. They are responsible for assessment of and monitoring of completion of staff competencies.

Registered Nursing Staff/ Health Care Assistants (HCA's) /Phlebotomists/Student Nurses/Midwifes must be trained and deemed competent to undertake the procedure and comply with this document. A copy of the competency should be held by the individual and work place.
Cannula insertion procedure
Peripheral cannulae are inserted by accredited practitioners, or under the direct supervision of accredited practitioners for the achievement of competency.

Peripheral cannulae may also be inserted by Authorised Non Registered Staff; when using a pre-filled proprietary flush only. This will include Band 4 Associate practitioners and other non-registered nursing staff in specialist areas as specifically identified by a DON/ADoN/M.
Nursing and midwifery students will also be permitted to insert peripheral cannulae following appropriate training and competency assessment. This must always be done under supervision.

Competency assessments of non-registered staff will be undertaken by a Clinical nurse educator/ Practice education facilitator /Development Nurse Specialist/Education Lead Nurse or Band 6 Sister/Charge Nurse.
Specialist areas are: A&E; The AMU's, X-ray department and the Haematology Day Unit
Indications for peripheral cannulation and MIDline
Cannulae will be placed for the following clinical indications;
Intravenous access when deemed essential
Fluid administration for re-hydration purposes, or to prevent dehydration when the oral route is inaccessible or inappropriate
Administration of medication unsuited to the oral route, or unavailable in oral form
Administration of blood or blood products
Indications for Midlines only
Midlines should only be used for the following clinical indications
Therapy lasting 2-4 weeks
The infusion of medication/fluids suitable for peripheral vessels only
Medication with pH between 5 and 9 osmolality
Contraindications for peripheral device (Cannula and MIDline)

Peripheral devices will not be routinely used for blood sampling, although blood may be taken using the vacutainer system, immediately on insertion. The practitioner should be aware this significantly increases the risk of haemolysis to the sample.
Blood cultures should not be taken from a peripheral device, even on insertion, due to an increased potential for contamination.

The practitioner must be able to clinically justify the siting of a peripheral device. Where this may not be immediately apparent, (i.e. emergency / anaesthetic access) the reason for insertion should be documented in the patient healthcare records. MIDlines are only inserted in Interventional Radiology (IR). The clinical indication for retaining a cannula/MIDline should be reassessed on a daily basis.

Peripheral cannulas/Midline should not be used for long term intravenous therapy or for the use of drugs that are considered irritants such as chemotherapy, parental nutrition and/or medications with osmolarity >900 0sm/l (Infusion Nurses Society, 2016 cited in RCN, 2016). PiCC should be considered in these cases alongside the Vessel Health Preservation Guidelines,
Cannula and site selection
Recommended sites are the veins of the dorsal and ventral aspects of the lower arm; the metacarpal, cephalic and basilic veins.
Avoid the following areas; lower extremities, areas of flexion, affected arm after mastectomy when lymph nodes have been removed or stroke, sites of fistula or graft.
The antecubital fossa should be avoided; except in an emergency situation when it is recommended.
If sites are not available seek expert help, review the need for the cannula and type of access device; alternatives are available for longer term intravenous access
If on assessment the procedure is deemed to be particularly difficult, the use of sterile gloves will reduce the risk of accidental contamination
Less experienced practitioners should not attempt to cannulate more than twice, seek expert help if failure occurs, to save the vein and instil patient confidence
In Paediatrics the most appropriate site available is chosen, which is determined by the child / baby's condition, age and size.
The device selected should normally be the smallest gauge and shortest length appropriate for the planned therapy, taking account of the Manufacturers guidelines as below (Taxis and Barber, 2003)
Non ported cannulae should be used where possible to reduce the potential for infection.

Ported cannulae may be used if deemed clinically appropriate, for example in an emergency situation, for a short-term procedure or in specific areas i.e. all theatre areas, maternity, for day stay investigations and in resuscitations areas
All intravenous devices will be protected through the use of a needle free access device; which will include an extension set for standard cannulae.
Available cannulas:
White  g for all Paediatric I.V. therapies
Yellow 24g for all Paediatric or neonatal patients, the elderly with fragile veins and
oncology patients undergoing chemotherapy.
I.V. therapies crystalloid flow rate 22ml/min
Blue 22g general use; crystalloid flow rate  -36ml/min
Pink 20g routine infusion therapies, blood components or large volumes;
crystalloid flow rate 60-61mls/min
Green 18g large volumes of fluid / surgery / rapid blood transfusion; crystalloid
flow rate 96 -100mls/min
Grey 16g rapid transfusion of whole blood or blood components, or viscous
fluids; crystalloid flow rate 196 -210mls/min
Orange 14g rapid transfusion of blood or blood components, or viscous fluids,
often used in emergency situations; crystalloid flow rate 343 - 345mls/min
NB 22g / 20g acceptable for Blood – see Blood and Blood Products Administration Procedure
MIDline selection

It is recommended that patients requiring intravenous access for up to 4 weeks rather than days, be referred for MIDline. Lines required for longer than 4 weeks or for patients requiring drugs that are considered an irritant, PICC placement is suggested to preserve the peripheral veins (NMC, 2010).

Site selection for MIDline placement is at the discretion of the specialist inserter in accordance with their protocols. They will be located in either the Basilic, Cephalic or Brachial vein above the antecubital fossa, though the tip remains in the peripheral circulation. (RCN, 2016)
Equipment for cannulation
Tourniquet, (disposable, single patient use) latex free
Gloves – non powdered, latex free
2% Chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol impregnated moist wipe e.g. Sani-cloth, clinell wipe, or in cases of allergy, povidone iodine in alcohol
Appropriate safety cannula, size dependant on the use
5mls 0.9% Sodium Chloride in a 10ml syringe for flushing; or for authorised non registered staff a pre-filled proprietary flush such as Posiflush®
Sterile transparent semi permeable dressing (i.e. ClearFilm IV 7x9cm)
Near point sharps tray and bin.
Sterile gauze swabs / (cotton wool – paediatrics)
Needle free access device primed with 0.9% sodium chloride
Prepared infusion with primed administration set, if prescribed.
Cannula insertion label to stick into patient notes
Ametop Cream as required, for use on children under the age of sixteen, or
any patient with pain/anxiety issues.
Procedure for insertion of a peripheral venous cannula
Explain procedure to patient / parents and allow time for them to ask questions and indicate consent (Consent should be obtained in line with Trust policy)
If indicated Ametop cream to be applied to and around the cannula insertion site. (Instructions on how to apply are provided with the cream)
Ensure that the working area is clean and has adequate lighting, ventilation, space and privacy.
Clean the tray with hot water and detergent if visibly soiled; prior to disinfection before each use with 70% alcohol / appropriate disinfectant wipe.
Ensure all equipment is to hand, place in cleaned tray. Put on apron, wash hands and then apply foam hand sanitiser to decontaminate hands

Gloves may be applied at this point; although it is acceptable to assess and palpate the vein without gloves (after hands have been decontaminated). Gloves must be worn before the needle touches the skin.
Support chosen limb.
Apply tourniquet 5-10cm above the chosen site

Thoroughly clean skin with 2% Chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol impregnated moist wipe (Sani-cloth CHG 2% or clinell wipe) and allow drying for 30 seconds. DO NOT re-palpate vein or touch the site of insertion; ensure gloves are on. NB: Chlorhexidine is a potential allergenic antiseptic; therefore, caution should be taken, ensuring patients are not allergic (Loveday et al, 2014).

For a ported cannula; remove cannula from the packet and inspect for damage, taking care needle does not move within cannula. Flatten wings and with index and middle fingers on wings and thumb on end of introducer, push together to ensure flashback chamber is secure, (may hear an audible click). NEVER withdraw the needle and replace.

When using a non-ported cannula, remove cannula from the packet and ensure the push plate is at the top, indicating the needle bevel is in the correct position. Take care the needle does not move within cannula. Flatten wings and hold the needle in place within the cannula for initial insertion.
Anchor the vein by applying traction on skin below proposed site. Insert the cannula at approximately 30⁰ ensuring bevel uppermost and observe for blood flashback
Release the tourniquet.

Place gauze under cannula hub and while applying occlusive pressure just beyond the cannula tip position, withdraw the needle and dispose of in the sharps bin at point of use. Non ported cannulae have a septum which minimises blood flow back, but it is essential to immediately attach the luer lock / needle free access device to cannula to prevent the ingress of micro-organisms.
Fix cannula in place with stabilising strips, and apply transparent dressing, (as per instructions in appendix I) ensuring adequate covering and visibility of
entry site.

Flush cannula with 5mls 0.9% normal saline, in a 10ml syringe (or larger), or a pre-filled proprietary flush. This limits the pressure exerted protecting the vein and device from damage. Smaller volumes will be used in paediatrics. (Please refer to IV Medication Policy).
Use a pulsatile, push /stop flush with positive pressure locking
Date the dressing once in place (N/A in paediatrics)
Remove gloves, dispose of equipment in accordance with infection prevention and wash hands.
Apply splint to paediatric patients as required
Complete documentation sticker and place in patient healthcare record at Basildon and Southend Hospitals, document on Vital Pac at broomfield. All documentation to include:
Date and time of insertion
Site of insertion
Gauge of cannula
By whom
Reason for insertion
Any failed attempts, marked F
Multiple attempts to cannulate are not recommended, to preserve venous integrity and patient confidence.

When suitable veins are not easily ‘visible or palpable escalate to anaesthetic teams or local vascular access teams' (Hallam et al, 2021) consider referral for a MIDline or PICC. See Peripherally Inserted Central Catheters (PiCC's) and Midline Management Policy for Adults (18 years and above) (or
equivalent).
Complications on insertion of a cannula include:
Phlebitis
Psychological trauma to the patient
Extravasation and infiltration of IV fluids
Trauma due to poor positioning and securing of the cannula
Catheter embolism
Air embolism
Penetration of a nerve
Haematoma
Puncturing an artery

These can be prevented by adequate assessment of peripheral vessels, knowledge of anatomy, good vein and device selection, and careful technique. If any complications do occur the health care professional undertaking the cannulation must inform the patient and/or relative, complete an online Datix, document in the patient's notes and ensure the patient is aware to inform a member of staff if they develop numbness or tingling.
Phlebitis
Phlebitis is the inflammation of a vein, or more specifically its inner lining, the tunica intima (RCN, 2016).
Mechanical Phlebitis: This is caused by the cannula rubbing the vein by stiff catheter, infusates or bacteria (Zhang et al, 2016).
Chemical Phlebitis: caused by the drug or fluid infused through the catheter, where factors such as pH and osmolality can significantly impact the incidence of phlebitis (Souza, 2016)
Infective/Bacterial Phlebitis: This occurs as a consequence of microorganisms

Entering the vein through the puncture site. These can originate from the patient's own resident skin flora or from cross-contamination of microorganisms onto the cannula site and injection ports. Infective phlebitis can be a consequence of poor hygiene from health care professionals.

The invasive device tool has the phlebitis scale within it which informs nurses of indications of phlebitis and the actions to take if phlebitis is suspected. Management of phlebitis would include removal of the device, warm or cold compressors applied to the affected site. If the rating of phlebitis is greater than 3 the medical physician's team looking after the patient should be made aware to review.
Extravasation

Accidental leakage into surrounding tissue from the vein usually occurring when intravenous (IV) medication passes from the blood vessels into the tissue around the blood vessels and beyond (RCN, 2016). Depending upon the substance that extravasates, injury can range from very mild skin reactions to necrosis
The risk of extravasation is increased in the following cases:
Very young or elderly patients
Female Gender
Unconscious, sedated or confused patients
Patients who have had multiple venepuncture or cannula sites
Lymphoedema
Patients suffering from decreased sensation or circulation
Patients with superior vena cava obstructions
Inadequate securing of the cannula
Inadequate visibility of the cannula and surrounding tissue
Vesicant and cytotoxic medications
Those with fragile veins or who are thrombocytopenic.
Obesity
(West Midlands Expert Advisory Group for Chemotherapy, 2017 and INS, 2021)

The practitioner must constantly assess the cannulation site and the surrounding tissue for any signs and symptoms of possible extravasation these may occur immediately after the blood vessel has been breached and may include:
Changes in sensation or pain including a burning or stinging.
Changes in infusion quality (e.g., free flowing IV slowing down)
Swelling at the cannulation site or along the vein pathway
Induration
Erythema
Venous discolouration/blanching
Sluggish or absence of blood return
Increased resistance when administering IV drugs
Inflammation or blistering
Leaking around the IV cannula site.
Vesicants are drugs (cytotoxic or non-cytotoxic) which can cause extravasation with the potential also to cause blistering and ulceration and if left untreated, tissue necrosis.
Some non-vesicants may still cause a reaction if they extravasate Desquamation- inflammation and shedding of the skin
Irritants - inflammation and irritation
Inflammation - mild to moderate inflammation and flare
Procedure for the IMMEDIATE management of peripheral extravasation
Stop and disconnect the infusion/ bolus immediately.
Explain to the patient what you suspect has happened.
Doctors caring for patient must review and decide on the management of extravasation complication with possibility of infusing a diluent to make the drug less vesicant.
Please refer to Management Of Extravasation guideline and Prevention And Management Of Extravasation With Cytotoxic Agents (or equivalent) for further guidance.
Infiltration

Infiltration is defined as the inadvertent administration of non-vesicant (non-caustic) medication or solution into the surrounding tissue instead of into the intended vascular pathway (Odom et al, 2018).
Should infiltration occur, administration of the medicine must be discontinued immediately and the peripheral cannula removed.
On-going monitoring is required due to the risk of compression to nerves and acute limb compartment syndrome – pain/sensation, pulse in limb, perfusion.
Doctors caring for patient must review and decide on the management of infiltration complication after discussing with the radiologist.
Documentation of Extravasation and Infiltration Documentation must include the following:
Date and time
Type and size of vascular access device
Location of device
Number and location of cannulation attempts
Estimated amount of extravasated/infiltrated drug
Symptoms reported by the patient
Description of device site
Assessment of limb
Immediate nursing interventions
Follow up interventions
Patient information
Haematoma
A haematoma is a localised collection of blood, usually clotted within tissue. The formation of haematoma can occur during insertion procedure or after removal of cannula.
Causes:
Penetration of the posterior wall
Incorrect choice of needle to vein size
Fragile veins
Patients on anticoagulant therapy
Application of a tourniquet to an extremity immediately after a venepuncture attempt
Inadequate pressure on venepuncture site on removal of cannula.
Prevention includes good vein selection with appropriate device size selection and careful technique.

In the event of a haematoma occurring, the needle should be removed immediately and pressure applied to the site for a few minutes. It may be appropriate to elevate the extremity, reassure the patient and explain what has happened.
Puncturing an artery
This would be characterised by the patient complaining of pain and visualising blood that is bright red in colour.
This can be prevented by adequate assessment and recognition of arteries prior to performing the cannulation procedure.
If during cannulation an artery is punctured, then pressure should be applied to the puncture site for up to 5 minutes. The patient should be reassured, given an explanation of what has happened.
Nerve Injury
If a nerve is accidently penetrated during insertion of a cannula into a vein, the patient may experience paraesthesia type pain eg, pain, burning or localised tingling, numbness (INS, 2021).
Prevention by ensuring the location of the superficial nerves is known by the practitioner inserting the cannula.
If a nerve is injured then the cannula should be removed immediately, the patient reassured and informed that they may experience some paraesthesia symptoms for a couple of hours or longer.
If symptoms get worse medical advice should be sought.
Monitoring and care of a peripheral venous cannula
This is the responsibility of all practitioners prior to accessing the cannula, and the registered practitioner caring for the patient.
Student nurses/midwives may only flush cannulae once they have competed training and always under the direct supervision of a competent Nurse/Midwife.

Authorised Non-Registered staff may undertake VIP scoring, dressing changes, flush to maintain patency using a pre-filled proprietary flush such as Posiflush®, and cannula removal when required; once trained and deemed competent.

Health Care Assistants (HCA's) do not access intravenous devices but may undertake cannula VIP scoring, dressing changes, or cannula removal when required, once trained and deemed competent. It is not acceptable for HCAs to disconnect IV infusions at any time, even once completed.

Monitoring of cannulae sites will be undertaken using the VIP scoring system documentation (Appendix 4) to ensure that all intravenous cannula sites are fit for use and facilitate early detection and treatment of any complications. At Southend site, the monitoring of the peripheral cannulae, including the VIP scoring system, must be documented on the IDT. At Broomfield this is completed on Vital Pac
This should be undertaken:
prior to accessing the device
8 hourly
(Loveday et al, 2014)
It is recommended that when the environment allows, VIP is also checked
Whenever the infusion rate is altered
Whenever the bag of infusate is changed
Flushing is required to check for position /patency;
On insertion
Prior to accessing the device
Before, between and after administration of medications; (see separate procedure)
Once each shift if the device is not in use (e.g., minimum twice daily) nb if cannula not in use for 24hrs, removal should be considered
If a peripheral cannula is to be retained when not in regular use, the clinical justification must be documented in the healthcare record
For a midline please report and seek advice from the picc/vascular access nurse or education facilitator or other competent practitioner before removing.
(Loveday et al, 2014)

The registered nurse or midwife caring for the patient is responsible for ensuring adequate checks are made if the device is not in regular use. In this instance the need for a cannula should be re-assessed and if there is no longer a clinical indication, removing it and documenting this in the healthcare record.
Equipment required for the flushing of peripheral venous cannulae
VIP scoring system: to assess site and guide management options (appendix 4)
Paediatrics (NICU) see specific cannula care plan; Peripheral intravenous access.

10ml syringe containing 5mls Sodium chloride 0.9% solution to flush, or for authorised non registered staff a pre-filled proprietary flush such as Posiflush® NB Paediatrics may require smaller volumes, dependent on age / size of patient but a 10ml syringe is required
Trust approved; 2% Chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol impregnated moist wipe e.g., Sani-cloth, clinell wipe, or in cases of allergy, povidone iodine in alcohol
Gloves non-powdered, latex free
Apron
Needle free access if not already in situ
NB Any intravenous access device sited to administer sedation or analgesia for a procedure must be adequately flushed or removed at the end of the procedure (NPSA 2017)
NB; please ensure the MSE IV Medication Policy is reviewed in conjunction with this policy for IV flushing guidelines.
Peripheral venous cannula or MIDline site dressing
Dressings should be changed if they are soiled, non-adherent, or the patient is exhibiting signs of allergy, and on a weekly basis for any cannula still in situ.
Dressing changes should be undertaken using an aseptic non touch technique; whereby the focus is on cleaning and not re-touching the insertion site.
Dressings should be sterile, transparent, self-adhesive and semi-permeable (Loveday et al, 2014).

NB in cases of allergy to the IV dressing the alternate version may still be suitable as the adhesive used is different. If not, a sterile dry gauze dressing will be required; this must be renewed at every VIP check.
Dressing changes may be undertaken by any healthcare worker trained and deemed competent by an accredited practitioner.
Equipment for the peripheral venous cannula or MIDline site dressing:
Apron
Latex free non powdered gloves
Hand sanitiser
Trust approved 2% Chlorhexidine in 70% isopropyl alcohol impregnated moist wipe e.g. Sani-cloth, clinell wipe, or in cases of allergy, povidone iodine in alcohol
Transparent semi-permeable membrane dressing (i.e.Tegaderm IV® or Opsite IV 3000®).
FOR MIDline ONLY: Chlorhexidine impregnated sponge i.e; Biopatch, around insertion site.
Procedure for peripheral venous cannulae or MIDline site dressing
Assemble equipment
Explain procedure to patient / parents and allow time for them to ask questions.
Wash hands and apply apron.
clear space / identify an area for the near point sharps tray
Decontaminate hands, prepare cannula dressing and open 2% Chlorhexidine in 70% alcohol wipe
Apply gloves and remove old dressing, (the strips may be retained at this point)
Clean site with chlorhexidine and alcohol wipe and allow drying. (The strips can be removed one at a time to facilitate this, stabilising the cannula through the wings
FOR MIDline ONLY: apply Biopatch. Biopatch® should be applied printed side up and have 360 ° contact with the skin around the catheter (Appendix 2)
Replace new stabilising strips and apply IV dressing to securely anchor the cannula, ensuring the entry site is adequately covered. (See appendix I for details)
Remove gloves
Decontaminate hands
Label dressing with time and date of original cannulation. (Adults only, Paediatric - document in notes / care plan or for neonates label the T piece closest to the cannula)
Dispose of waste in accordance with Trust's Standard principles for preventing hospital acquired infections, and wash hands.
Document dressing change, and status of site in the patient's healthcare records/ Intravenous Cannula Care Plan, utilising VIP scoring (see appendix
Peripheral venous cannula removal
The removal of an intravenous cannula is an aseptic non-touch technique, in order to reduce the risk of microbial contamination from external sources.
This will be undertaken:
When the cannula is no longer required
VIP score is identified of 2 or more
The cannula is damaged or misplaced / signs of infiltration are present
Equipment for the removal of a peripheral venous cannula
Sterile gauze swabs x 2 / cotton wool in Paediatrics
Near point sharps bin with tray cleaned as per Trust policy
Latex free disposable gloves
Dressing (sterile)
Tape
Procedure for the removal of a peripheral venous cannula
Explain the procedure to the patient / parents and allow time for them to ask questions.
Ensure that equipment is ready.
Wash and dry hands and apply hand sanitiser.
Apply gloves.
Support limb and loosen dressing.
Cover the entry site with sterile gauze / cotton wool and gently withdraw cannula in precise line with original insertion.
Using the gauze / cotton wool, apply firm pressure directly over the insertion site.
Inspect the cannula to ensure the tip is intact prior to disposal
Maintain pressure for approx. 2 minutes before checking that the bleeding has ceased and assessing the site

If signs and symptoms of infection are present, obtain a swab for culture and sensitivity; e.g. pyrexia, redness, inflammation, tenderness, pain, pus, etc., in which instance the site should be cleaned and redressed after swabbing
Apply a suitable dressing.
Dispose of cannula and the rest of the equipment as per the MSEPO-21112 Waste Management Policy and Procedure.
Remove gloves, and decontaminate hands as per infection control policies.
Document the procedure, the state of the cannula site and the general condition of the patient in the patient's healthcare records. The site should be re-checked after 24hrs.
MIDline removal can only be undertaken by the following registrants:
Registered nurses who hold a competency
PICC Team
Medical personnel
NB This may involve the removal of a Securacath device, seek advice if unsure.
Equipment required to remove a MIDline:
Near point sharps tray cleaned as per Trust policy
Apron
Latex free non powdered gloves
Hand sanitiser
2% Chlorhexidine/70% alcohol wipes (Clinell® or SaniCloth®)
Sterile gauze
An occlusive dressing such as Mepore®
Procedure for removing a MIDline:
Assemble equipment
Explain procedure to patient and allow time for them to ask questions.
Place the patients arm in a comfortable position that allows access to the Mid-line.
Wash hands and don apron and gloves
Remove dressing and any securement device then clean the insertion site with 2% chlorhexidine/70% alcohol wipe and allow drying.
Gently pull-on MIDline to remove.
Once out apply pressure to the exit site with sterile gauze until there is no evidence of bleeding. Apply an occlusive dressing.
Once the MIDline has been removed, if present, the SecurAcath® can be removed using the “Fold” method in Appendix . A removal video can also be accessed via the PiCC Team page on the Trust Intranet
Dispose of all waste as per Trust policy
Document removal in patient's healthcare records.
Training requirements
Medical Training

The competencies of trainee doctors are set by their Foundation School (foundation doctors) or Speciality Schools (Core trainees and Registrars) and are taught to undergraduates in medical school. Therefore, competence in cannulation is undertaken as part of the standard curricula of various trainee levels. All doctors must make themselves familiar with both the Trust policy and procedure for Cannulation insertion and care, and the relevant equipment. FY1 doctors receive refresher training during induction and should keep a record of assessments in clinical practice.

Medical staff are also trained and assessed as competent to administer Intravenous drugs during medical training, they are responsible for ensuring they remain up to date and familiar with Trust policies and equipment for drug administration.
Cannulation training for all other staff
For all other relevant staff, the decision to undertake IV cannulation training must be justified and agreed between the individual staff member and the Ward / Department or Area Manager.

Staff undertaking the IV cannulation training must have completed the Trust online learning module or paper workbook, followed by face-to-face practical training and be assessed and signed as competent before practicing independently. Completed competency (site specific) should be held by the staff member and ward manager in the staff file.

Staff who fail to complete pre-course training should seek advice from their local education team where efforts to assist with learning can be agreed before staff are re-entered for the cannulation course.

The IV Cannulation trainer has the right to discontinue training / assessment if the trainee is considered unlikely to achieve practical competence. The member of staff and the Ward / Department / Area Manager will be notified of this decision and the reasons behind the decision in writing.

Staff undertaking the IV cannulation must have completed their practical competencies within three months of the IV cannulation training session. It is the member of staff's responsibility to arrange, and undergo supervised practice prior to assessment of competence. If the competencies have not been completed the member of staff will not be able to perform IV cannulation without attending another study session.

Training must reflect the latest authoritative opinion on cannula insertion as directed by Evidence Based Practice in Infection Control (EPIC). Training must include any changes as a result of National Institute of Clinical (NICE) or National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) Guidance.
Cannula care is taught during cannulation training and practised under the supervision of accredited practitioners and registered nurses within the clinical areas.
HCA's and other authorised non registered staff are taught cannulation care in practice by competent registered nurses.

Registered practitioners new to the Trust with evidence of previous cannulation training and competency may be assessed against Trust competencies, after familiarisation with local equipment and procedures, at the Ward Managers' discretion. A single assessment of each procedure is sufficient, to provide a current record.
Student Nurses/midwives
Cannulation for student nurses and midwives is a standard of proficiency required for completion of the student nurse/midwife training (NMC, 2018).

During the third year of training ONLY, Student nurses/midwives will be expected to undertake MSE trust training in form of a theoretical workbook followed by simulation practical training. Once the theoretical and simulation practice training has been completed the student nurse/midwife may practice this skill under supervision of a registered nurse/midwife who has completed the Standards for Supervision and Assessment training (Part1 and Part 2).
Student nurses/midwives MUST always practice cannulation under supervision.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committee, Practice Education Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local peripheral cannulation guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the Infection Prevention and Control Committee, Practice Education Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 5)

Appendix 1: Intravenous dressing application instructions
Step 1   Step 2

data.url: MSEPO-21199 Canulation insertion and care Policy.003.png

data.text: Peel open the package and remove the sterile dressing. Remove centre cut out, then remove sterile pre-cut tape strips.
Step 3   Step 4

data.url: MSEPO-21199 Canulation insertion and care Policy.006.png

data.text: Place the strips over the cannula wings for added security. Peel paper liner from framed dressing exposing adhesive surface
Step 5
Place dressing over cannula so that transparent film covers the insertion site. Position the soft cloth tape section over the cannula wings with the port at the end of the deep notch.

data.url: MSEPO-21199 Canulation insertion and care Policy.007.png

data.text: Step 6  Step 7

data.url: MSEPO-21199 Canulation insertion and care Policy.009.png

data.text: Overlap each side of the soft cloth tape underneath the port hub.
Then remove the paper frame and smooth the dressing edges to increase adhesion.
Place record label near to / on the dressing. Ensure the date sticker does not cover the insertion site. NB; always label with date of cannulation, not dressing change.
Removal Instructions
Remove record label
Alternately stretch and release the film section parallel to the skin to break the adhesive bond
Carefully peel back soft cloth tape in the direction of hair growth
Peel off the soft cloth strips

Appendix : Preliminary equality analysis
This assessment relates to Cannulation insertion and care policy: (Please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
The aim of the change to this policy is to standardise practice throughout the 3 MSE sites for cannulation and IV drug administration.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Each site currently follows an individual policy, by changing this our patients will receive the same standard of care on each site.
Who benefits from this change and how?

Patients and staff will benefit from this as best practice care will be standardised, staff will feel confident to use this skill on all 3 sites and patients will receive the same standard of care throughout
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
Yes, Staff may initially have to familiarise themselves and become confident with new practices.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
